Plate Ware Used: Large round plate Method:
1. Spread tomato sauce evenly across dough leaving a half inch boarder for the crust.
2. Top with mozza cheese evenly covering the base of the dough.
4. place slices of marinated bocconcini across the base of the dough on top of the mozza.
5. Using a lightly floured peel transfer the raw pizza into the forno to bake (aprox 8-9 minutes) crust should be baked through and golden on the edges.
6. Again using the peel remove the fully baked pizza from the forno oven. On the cutting board using the pizza knife cut into 10 equal slices, garnish with fresh basil and serve imediately.

1 - Preheat tilt fryer to 375

1) Preheat oven to 375*F
2) Place bones on roasting pan or baking sheet and place in oven to roast until golden brown, about 2 hours. Ensure to move bones around and rotate pan to ensure bones are evenly browned.
3) Once roasted, place bones in large stock pot or steam kettle. Cover bones with water until just a small amount of bones are sticking out of water. Bring to a simmer.
4) Once a simmer is achieved, skim any impurities that rise to the top. Continue skimming and simmering for at least four hours.
5) Add rough chopped onion, celery, and carrot and bay leaf to stock. Allow to simmer for another 4-8 hours (or overnight).
6) Remove stock from heat. Remove bones with tongs and reserve. Using a pitcher and fine chinous, strain stock into appropriate vessel. Bones can be covered again with water to make remoulage.

1) With pork belly skin side down, rub belly with Porchetta Rub generously.
2) Roll belly into a tight log. You may need a buddy to help you hold the belly in place. Tie butchers knots on each end of porchetta than one good tie in the middle to secure. Continue making butchers knots 1" apart until fully tied.
3) Combine kosher salt and baking powder. Rub over skin of porchetta.
4) Store in fridge, uncovered for at least 24 hours, or up to 3 days.
5) Preheat oven to 300*F. Place porchetta seam side down on cooling rack inside of roasting rack. Roast until internal temperature of 60*C (140*F) is reached.
6) Increase oven temperature to 500*F and roast for 20-30 minutes until skin is blistered and very crispy.
7) Rest for 15 minutes and serve.

1) Rinse and drain bean sprouts under cold running water very well. Allow to drain
2) Combine slaw mixture, angle cut green onion, julienne red onion, daikon and asian slaw dressing. Toss well to incorporate and evenly distribute dressing.
4) Store in appropriate container. Label, date, refrigerate.

1) In a large stock pot over medium high heat, add oil. When oil is hot, add onion. Saute for 3-4 minutes. Add chili flakes and continue sauteing for 1 minute.
2) Add carrot, celery, wild rice and seasoning and continue sauteing for 3-4 minutes. Add stock and crushed tomato and bring to a simmer. Continue simmering for 8-10 minutes or until vegetables are tender.
3) Take soup off heat and add chick peas and parsley. Stir well to combine, trying not to squish chick peas too much. Taste for seasoning. Adjust if necessary.
4) Add to appropriate sized cambro and place in blast chiller. Chill until probe thermometer inserted in middle of soup reaches 4*C or lower. Label, date, refrigerate.

1) In a large china cap strainer, add lentils. Rinse lentils under running water, set aside. Trim kale and cut or tear into bite sized pieces. Set aside.
2) In large stock pot over medium high heat, add oil. When oil is hot, add onion, garam masala, turmeric, and curry powder. Saute onions and spices until the spice is cooked out, about 8-10 minutes. Add garlic and ginger purees and saute for another 2-3 minutes.
3) Add diced carrot and onion and saute for another 2-3 minutes. Add lentils, seasoning, canned tomatoes and stock and bring to a simmer. Simmer for about 10 minutes or until lentils are just al dente, and carrots are tender. Add kale and stir in to wilt.
4) Taste for seasoning and adjust if necessary. Place in appropriate sized cambro and place in blast chiller. Chill soup until probe thermometer reads 4*C or lower. Label, date, refrigerate.

1) Make veg stock as per recipe.
2) Dice carrots nad oninos using 3/4" attachment for robot coupe dicer. If you have never used it, just ask Chef or a 1st cook for help setting it up.
3) In a large rondeu or stock pot over medium high heat, add oil. When oil is hot, add onion. Saute for 5 minutes or until onion is beginning to soften.
4) Add garlic puree, ginger puree, nutmeg and seasoning. Continue sauteing another two minutes or until ginger and garlic is nice and fragrant. Add carrots and saute for another 2-3 minutes.
5) Add vegetable stock and bring to a simmer. Allow to simmer for 10 minutes or until carrots are soft and able to blend easily.
6) Using an immersion blender, puree soup until its nice and smooth. Taste for seasoning and adjust if necessary. Use immidiatley for service, or if making in advance, place in shallow hotel pans and put in blast chiller. Chill until probe thermometed inserted into middl of soup registers 4*C or lower. Label, date, refrigerate.

1) In large stock pot over medium high heat, add oil. When oil is hot, add onion and saute for 3-4 mintues or until beginning to soften. Add garlic puree and saute 1 minute more.
2) Add wine and balsamic vinegar and continue sauteing until au sec (almost dry). Add brown sugar and seasoning and stir well to combine.
3) Add crushed tomato, diced tomato, and veg stock and bring to a simmer. Simmer for 8 - 10 minutes, or until all flavours are combined really well.
4) Puree with immersion blender, then add chopped parsely and chiffonade basil. Taste for seasoning. If your happy with it, put in appropriate sized cambro and put in blast chiller. Chill until instant read probe thermometer reads 4*C or lower. Label, date, refrigerate.

1) Tie up thyme leaves with butchers twine and reserve for making soup.
2) Set tilt kettle to 350*F /medium high heat, add oil. Once oil is hot, add onion and saute for 3-4 minutes until beginning to soften. Add garlic puree and saute 1 minute more.
3) Add mushrooms and really utilize the space of the tilt kettle to brown mushrooms. Really spread them out and let them go. Don't stir constantly.
4) Add celery, marjoram, thyme bundle and seasoning once mushrooms are browned and saute for another 3-4 minutes.
5) Add stock and bring to a simmer. Allow to simmer for 10 minutes or until celery is very tender.
6) Blend soup well with immersion blender, then add cream and stir well. Taste for seasoning and adjust if necessary.
7) Place in appropriate sized cambro container and put in blast chiller. Allow to chill until probe themometer inserted into middle of soup registers 4*C or lower. Label, date, refrigerate.
Allergens:
Dairy/Milk

1) In large stock pot over medium high heat, add oil. When oil is hot, add onion and saute for 2-3 minutes. Add smoked paprika and garlic puree and saute for another 2-3 minutes, or until the paprika is cooked out and onions are tender.
2) Add chipotle, carrot, yam and celery and continue sauteing for 3-4 minutes. Add corn and saute 1 minute more. Add stock and bring to a simmer for about 8-10 minutes or until vegetables are tender.
3) Take off heat, and add green peppers, cream and chopped cilantro. Stir very well to incorporate. Taste for seasoning. Adjust if necessary. Place in appropriate sized container and put in blast chiller. Continue chilling until a probe thermometer inserted in middle of soup registers 4*C. Label, Date, Refrigerate.

1. Roast the beef bones for 1 hour at 375-400* then apply the tomato paste and roast for another 40 minutes to and hour.
2. While the bones are roasting - sautee your onions, garlic, leek, carrot and celery on medium heat. Once the onions are soft, add the spices and sautee for another 5 min before putting everything into the steam kettle.
3. Cover the veggies with water and add the bones - bring to a boil and then reduce to just below a simmer. Let it ride for overnight to develop the full flavour - then the next day turn off and add all the vegetable ends and fresh herbs(thyme or rosemary) and let sit for another 30 minutes.
4. Skim off extra fat, strain, downsize and cool down.
The salt in this recipe is an approximate ammount to season the broth if you are using it in a soup etc...

1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
2. Dock the bottom of the pastry (to allow air to escape so it doesn't bubble) Bake the crust for about 5-10 minutes.
3. Remove from the oven and allow to cool. The crust will be golden. but not not too dark. (as it will bake again with custard/filling
4. Prepare the egg custard mixture by adding the eggs to a large measuring cup. Add the heavy cream, then add the milk, salt and pepper.
5. Blend with a hand mixer to ensure the egg and cream mixture is completely homogenous (mixed thouroughly)
6. Spread the desired fillings on the bottom of the pie crust. Pour the egg mixture on top (leave a half CM of head space at the top of the quiche as the eggs will souffle and expand) Bake at 350 degrees for about 20-25 minutes (check after 15 mins) The quiche will be slightly wobbly in just the center.(this allows for carry over cooking and will set up within a few minutes of exiting the oven)
7. Allow to cool for about 20 minutes to room temperature. Quiche can be served warm, cold, or room temperature.

ALLERGENS: MUSTARD, NON-HALAL (WINE IN THE MUSTARD).
Notes:
This is not a traditional Vindaloo, but no one really has a good idea of what Vindaloo is - really. Many British adopters of Indian cuisine, when it hit England, didn't know that they were eating a Vindaloo made by predominantly Sri Lankan immigrants that the British just assumed were Indian. These immigrants from Sri Lanka, who ended up being lumped into British society as essentially a sub-brand of Indian people, were largely different from the majority of East Indians because they mostly Muslim.
The dish was originally a cultural mash-up that was born out of Portuguese colonial influence in Goa. It was originally made with Pork and Wine Vinegar -but, since Sri Lankans are mostly Muslim, the dish became wine-less and pork-less (Lamb, Goat, and Beef stepped in to create what most now understand as what the dish should be), and was hence reborn under the name Vindaloo in 1950's/60's Britain as what people assume it to be today. Like many Indian dishes, it has a rich history - just lesser known, in its essential details, than others. This recipe for the base paste is somewhere between its original ethos, and its modern twists.
Prep:
- THE NIGHT BEFORE: Open up the can of Roasted Red Peppers. Add Chili Flakes, and Red Wine Vinegar. Soak overnight. You can also put together your spices the day before - this would be wise, no?
- THE DAY OF: Process Onions however you'd like. This mix will be puree'd once it's cooked out.
- Begin to cook out Onions. Caramelization is fine - high heat is best. Toast Spices. Add Garlic and Ginger - cook those out. Add Dijon Mustard, and cook out slightly. Then! Add Water, and let simmer. Add soaked mixture of Roasted Red Peppers, Chilis, and Vinegar, from th previous day.
- Simmer for 30-45 minutes, and then puree with an Immersion Blender until it becomes a fine paste.
- Label / Date / Store Appropriately...
***This recipe can be made in advance in large batches, and then vac-packed and frozen for future use.
Any questions? - Ask Chef...

METHOD:
Prep:
- This recipe should take 2 days - no more, no less, however, the curing process can be elongated, depending on time, to 3-4 days.
- TO CURE: Take Brown Sugar, and Salt - and rub the Pork Belly down thoroughly. Place in a Hotel Pan, SKIN SIDE DOWN, and let the sugar and salt begin drawing out moisture and breaking down the outside of the Belly. IMPORTANT: in the morning, when you come in for your shift the next day - TURN THE PORK BELLY OVER, SO THAT THE SKIN SIDE IS UP AND OPEN TO THE AIR.
- Pre-Heat the Convection Oven to 325F/180C.
- Cover Pork Belly with remaining ingredients, and roast for 25 minutes. Then, turn the oven to 425F, and finish for and extra 10-15 minutes.
- Once Pork Belly is cool, remove its skin layer and discard. Cut the meat, and prepare for next steps.

1. Zest and juice your 2 lemons.
2. Finely chop dill.
3. Process Cucumbers. These should be pulsed in the RoboCoupe. PULSED - NOT LEFT ON TO BECOME A SOUP. What you want is something about the consistency of a small dice. When this is done, transfer this mixture into a bowl with Cheese Cloth. RING OUT AS MUCH WATER AS YOU CAN. THIS WATER IS DELICIOUS. I RECOMMEND DRINKING IT FOR ITS ELECTROLYTE PROPERTIES. Unfortunately, it just doesn't belong in the Yoghurt in this recipe, as it would turn into Cacic.
4. Combine lemon juice and garlic. Let sit for 10 minutes. Salt this mixture to "cook out" the garlic as much as possible.
5. Fold all ingredients into one another. Taste for Salinity, Acidity, and add honey if the Sweetness needs a little kick.

Utensils needed:
NOTES: It's important to note that this is an opportunity for using old or slightly old Cucumber! For instance: look at the recipe for Taboulleh Salad Mix - Cucumber cores should be saved, and then processed and strained in Cheese Cloth for this recipe - otherwise it will be too watery.
In Turkey, there is a dish known as Cacic - a watery version of Tzatziki. The ingredients are more or less the same. What we know as Tzatziki is actually made with Labneh, which is pressed Yoghurt. Since we use regular Yoghurt in this recipe, we have to limit the amount of water content in it, otherwise it will be an undesirable AND low-quality product.

1) In large stock pot over medium high heat, add oil. When oil is hot, add diced onions, curry powder, ground coriander and ground cumin. Cook onions in spices until spices are cooked out and onions are very tender about 8 - 10 minutes.
2) Add garlic and ginger puree and saute 2-3 minutes more.
3) Add diced anise, carrot, celery, yam and salt & pepper. Saute 2-3 minutes more.
4) Add stock and bring to a simmer. Simmer for about 8-10 minutes or until vegetables are tender. Remove from heat. Stir in coconut milk, 1/4" diced apples and lemon juice. Taste for seasoning.
******IF YOU INTEND TO SERVE THIS SOUP RIGHT AWAY AFTER PREPARING, ADD 1 KG BROWN RICE AT THIS POINT. TAKE IT FROM THE VEG STATION AND STIR INTO SOUP. PLACE IN SOUP TERRINE AND SERVE IMMIDIATELY*****
5) If your happy with the taste of the soup, place in large cambro container and put in blast chiller. Chill to below 4*C. Label, Date, Refrigerate.
6) When reheating soup for service, bring up to a simmer and just before putting in soup terrine, take some rice from the veg station and add to soup. Stir to incorporate and put on soup bar immidiately.

1) In large stock pot over medium high heat, add oil. When oil is hot, add diced onion, all spice, cardamom, crushed red chili, corander, cumin, nutmeg, smoked paprika, turmeric and cinnamon. Saute onions and spices until they are really cooked out, about 8-10 minutes. Add garlic puree and continue sauteing for another 2-3 minutes.
2) Add carrots, celery and swet potatoes and continue sauteing for about 3-4 minutes.
3) Add lentils, stock, salt and pepper and tomatoes with juice and bring to a simmer. Simmer for about another 10 minutes or until vegetables and lentils are al dente. Taste for seasoning. Adjust if necessary.
4) Remove soup from heat and add in diced red peppers and spinach. Stir well to oncorporate.
5) Place soup in appropriate sized cambro and place in blast chiller. Chill soup until a probe thermometer inserted in soup registers 4*C or lower. Label, date, refrigerate.

1) In a large stock pot over medium high heat, add oil. When oil is hot, add onion. Saute onion for 3-4 minutes, or until beginning to soften. Add garlic puree and saute 1 minute more.
2) Add mushroom and saute until starting to brown. Seriously, don't let them steam. Cook them in batches if you need to, just don't crowd them too much, or else they will be mushy and gross.
3) Add diced carrots, celery and seasoning. Continue sauteing until carrot sare beginning to soften, about 3-4 minutes.
4) Add canned tomatoes and stock and bring to a simmer. Simmer for 8-10 minutes or until vegetables are nice and tender. Taste for seasoning. If your happy with it, remove soup from heat and stir in drained chickpeas and chopped parsley.
5) Place soup in blast chiller. Chill until probe themometer inserted in middle of soup registers 4*C or less. Label, date, refrigerate.

1) In large stock pot over medium high heat add oil. When oil is hot, add onion. Saute for 3-4 minutes, then add garlic puree. Saute 1 minute more.
2) Add dried oregano, seasoning, diced anise, carrots, and celery. Saute for 3-4 minutes more.
3) Add stock and bring to a simmer. Simmer until vegetables are tender, about 8-10 minutes. Taste for seasoning.
4) Remove soup from heat and add spinach and drained chick peas. Check seasoning again.
5) If reheating soup for service, bring to a simmer in large stock pot.
Place on soup bar immidiately.

1) Tie up rosemary and thyme using string so it's easy to fish out later. Rough Dice up apples, ensuring to remove core. They don't have to be pretty, this soup is going to be pureed.
2) In large stock pot over medium heat, add oil. When oil is hot, add onion, cinnamon and nutmeg and saute for about 4-5 minutes. Add garlic and ginger puree and saute for another 1-2 minutes.
3) Add diced butternut squash, carrot and apples and anise and salt and pepper. Saute for another 3-4 minutes, or until apples begin to soften.
4) Add stock, herb bundle and bring to a simmer. Simmer for about 8-10 minutes or until vegetables are tender.
5) Remove herb bundle, and puree the hell out of the soup using an immersion blender. Keep going until soup is nice and smooth. Do a small victory jig.
6) Taste soup for seasoning. If your happy with it, store in appropriate sized cambor and place in blast chiller until a probe thermometer inserted in soup reads below 4*C. Label, date, refrigerate.

Prep:
- Roasting Grape Tomatoes: Lightly Oil, Roast @ 400 for 5-8 minutes. Skins should be blistered, but bodies still intact.
- Grilling Avocados: Cut the avocado from pole to pole around its pit, and de-pit. Lightly oil the inside of the avocado with your finger, and salt. Grill on high heat - face down - for 4-6 minutes. Leave like this in your Mise En Place, and spoon out as necessary into Magda's Late Night Menu bowls.
- Frying Chickpeas: if you can't simply hydrate chickpeas overnight and fry them from beginning to end in the deep fryer, then you're going to have to use chickpeas from a can. Doing this is fine, but you'll have to make sure that you fry them until almost all of their moisture is gone - and this can take a while. An under-fried chickpea will go soft and unpleasant very quickly in a fridge. So, please fry adequately, and then drain properly on paper towel after frying to remove excess oils, and salt lightly.
Assembly:
1) Quinoa 2) Spinach 3) Arugula 4) Grilled Avocado 5) Fried Chickpeas 6) Roasted Grape Tomatoes 7) Lemon-Shallt Dressing

Prep:
- Cut all vegetables into large pieces. Do not spend more than 10 minutes cutting these vegetables, as all of them will be discarded, and no one will see your lovely cuts if you put effort into them.
- Heat a pot in the background with a small amount of oil. You can even start this process with water if you want. Start cooking out anything in the onion family first - this approach can be used with all stock making.
- Once you've cooked out your onions (can no longer smell gas coming off of them, and you start to smell sugars coming from them), then add all remaining ingredients EXCEPT CILANTRO - as well as water - and bring to a boil.
- When the pot is at a boil - let boil for about 20 minutes. Then, turn it down to a simmer. ADD CILANTRO (stocks and all), simmer for 40 minutes with salt, and take off heat. Once off heat, let rest for 45 minutes to an hour, and strain using the fine chinois.
- Label / date / store appropriately.

- PRE-SOAK Beans overnight! - 2 X 20L CAMBRO Containers - HALF of the Beans in Each - Filled with 12L of Water Each
- Using the Small Steam Kettle, Cook Beans slowly in 20 extra liters of water. They should be good to start at 250F.
- Make a "Sachet D'epices" (Sac of Spice) using cheesecloth - contain the Bay Leaf and Garlic in them, and allow them to steep for the duration of cooking with the beans.
- Cook the beans until they are soft, but not decomposing. During this process it is important to skim off the foamy protein that will accumulate at the surface of the cooking beans' water - this, if unchecked, will lead to a poor bitter taste and a lesser shelf life for the beans themselves.
- Turn off Steam Kettle when the beans are cooked, and let beans sit. Take 4L of the cooking water, and set aside.
- Drain beans, and then transfer them into a neutral container greater than 40L in volume. Get the large Hand Blender / Immersion Blender.
- Add the remaining ingredients - Olive Oil, Fennel, Salt, Lemon (ZEST AND JUICE, BUT BE CAREFUL OF SEEDS), and add in the 4L of reserved cooking water until the desired consistency is reached.
- The mixture should be a puree - not a soup, but, keep in mind that it will set significantly when it is cool versus warm/hot.
- Cool, Vaccuum Pack, Label/Date, and Store. This can be a frozen item that you can pull as needed.

ALLERGENS: GLUTEN (HOISIN)
Prep:
- Assemble: Black Cardamom, Star Anise, Coriander Seed, Cinnamon, and Nutmeg. Toast spices until fragrant, and then create a Sachet D'Epices with it, using cheesecloth and cooking twine.
- Pick: Celery Leaves, and Cilantro leaves from Stems. Keep the Stems of the Cilantro and the Celery Leaves separately (together). The Celery Stalks will be used in the making of the stock; the Cilantro Leaves will be used as garnish when serving; the Cilantro Stems and Celery Leaves will be added to the final step of the stock as aromatics.
- Peel Daikon completely and cut into 2" round pieces. Do the same with the White Onions in this recipe. Grill both of these until blackened on both sides - essentially burnt. This is important to the process.
- Place these burnt Daikon and Onion pieces into a large hotel pan, and then add: Cabbage, Garlic, Ginger, and Celery Stalks. Steam for 30 minutes, allowing water to accumulate in the hotel pan throughout the process.
- Fill the Steam Kettle with the 50 L of water in this recipe. Turn on, and begin heating.
- When the steaming ingredients are done, add to the Steam Kettle. When this is done, bring the mixture to a boil, and add the Sachet D'Epices. At this point, add Soy Sauce, Tamarind Paste, Brown Sugar, and Rice Vinegar.
- This stock can be done overnight, but it is not necessary. It should reach a boil for an hour - at least - and then it should reduce to a simmer, and be left for at least 2 hours. During the simmering process, salt can be added to taste. 200 grams are listed in the recipe, but this is an approximation.
- When heat is reduced to a simmer, add Cilantro Stems and Celery Leaves, and turn heat off all together. Allow these to steap for half an hour at least, and give the mixture a good stir before straining.
Label / Date / Store Appropriately!

Related Products this prep gets used in: Allergens: (to be filled out by nutrition) Method:
1. - PRE-SOAK Beans overnight! - 2 X 20L CAMBRO Containers - HALF of the Beans in Each - Filled with 12L of Water Each
2. Drain Beans from their hydration liquid. Your cooking water should be different from your soaking water.
3. Using the Small Steam Kettle, Cook Beans slowly in 20 extra liters of water. They should be good to start at 250F.
4. Cook the beans until they are soft, but not decomposing. During the cooking process it is important to skim off the foamy protein that will accumulate at the surface of the cooking beans' water - this, if unchecked, will lead to a poor bitter taste and a lesser shelf life for the beans themselves.
5. While the beans are cooking, saute your onions in Canola Oil, until dark brown. Caramelize them as far as they will go, and then add Cumin and Garlic. Saute Cumin and Garlic for 5 minutes, and then take off heat.
6. Turn off Steam Kettle when the beans are cooked, and let beans sit. Take 4L of the cooking water, and set aside.
7. Drain beans, and then transfer them into a neutral container greater than 40L in volume. Get the large Hand Blender / Immersion Blender.
8. Add the Onion mixture with the Garlic and Cumin, as well as half of the Salt. The remaining halves - set aside, and use to SEASON TO TASTE.
9. With the Hand Blender / Immersion Blender, blend about 4L of the bean mixture into a puree - and then add back into the rest of the beans, and mix. Add reserve liquid from the cooking, until you get - not a soup - beans with a puree of more beans.

ALLERGENS: GLUTEN, NOT HALAL (BEER/STOUT, LAMB)
Notes:
It is important to separate this recipe into 4 parts: Lamb, Sauce, Vegetables, and Dumplings (See Recipe). It is also important to note that this dish is full of carbohydrates, and that it is a stand-alone dish – know this when serving, when the students are free to ask questions (that you should know the answers to).
Prep:
- Start by getting the Lamb (3/4” Dice) into Deep Hotel Pans for braising. Pre-heat an oven to 325F, and talk to your co-workers about using that oven for 3-4 hours. Each Hotel Pan should be able to accommodate at least 7.5Kg of Lamb – up to 10Kg. You want to leave space in these braising pans for lots of water, and stout. Each pan should have AT LEAST 8 litres of water for braising – and should be uncovered for best results for the first 2 hours.
- After 2 hours of braising, take the foil off the top of the braising pans, and stir thoroughly.
- Check after 3 hours again, and see if the Lamb is nice and tender. You don’t want the Lamb to be falling apart, but you do want it to have shed some of its toughness. If the Lamb is not done, check every 20-30 minutes, stirring more often, until desired tenderness is achieved.
- Remove braising Lamb from the oven – and when cool, drain off the liquids in the braise, and downsize into a smaller number of pans.
- Put the braising liquid in a fridge to cool, which will allow the Lamb fat to separate from the stock that should be your other braise bi-product. You will make a Roux with the Lamb fat.
- The Sauce will start simply, as most sauces do. Get your Onions, Celery (3Kg for Sauce: 3Kg for Vegetables), Garlic, and Leek – rough chop them, and begin sautéing – Onions and Garlic first. Once the Garlic and Onions are cooked out – add the reserved Lamb liquid to the mixture, and let simmer.
- You may need to add a little more water to this. Don’t worry – it will have enough flavour. You want to make as much of this Sauce as you can, since this is a big batch size.
- Once this Sauce is boiling, use the Roux that you made out of the Lamb fat, and the Immersion Blender, to blend the Roux into the sauce to thicken it. You will want to turn the heat down on this pot, as the Roux will be tempted to burn if you do this on high heat. Within a few minutes, the gluten will cook out, and you’ll know the thickness of your sauce shortly after that. Season then, to taste.
- Meanwhile, begin processing the Vegetables and Herbs for this recipe in the background. Have the Herbs picked. The Vegetables can be cut in advance, and even cooked off in advance.
- All of the Vegetables – Parsnips, Rutabaga (Turnip), and Celery – would be best steamed until cooked, and then roasted at 350F in the Convection ovens for 15-20 minutes.
- When these are done, they can be set aside to be combined with everything else in this next step.
- When combining everything – Dumplings, braised Lamb, Vegetables, Sauce – the last things to add will be the herbs, and the peas. The peas will add a small amount of moisture and flavour to the batch, and the Herbs will finish it off. Go overboard on the herbs, making sure that everything that is ordered is in this recipe, and not waiting to die in our Produce Fridge’s shelves. The more herbs – the better!
Any Questions? Ask Chef…

1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
2. Dock the bottom of the pastry (to allow air to escape so it doesn't bubble) Bake the crust for about 5-10 minutes.
3. Remove from the oven and allow to cool. The crust will be golden. but not not too dark. (as it will bake again with custard/filling
4. Prepare the egg custard mixture by adding the eggs to a large measuring cup. Add the heavy cream, then add the milk, salt and pepper.
5. Blend with a hand mixer to ensure the egg and cream mixture is completely homogenous (mixed thouroughly)
6. Spread the desired fillings on the bottom of the pie crust. Pour the egg mixture on top (leave a 1/2 cm of head space at the top of the quiche as the eggs will souffle and expand) Bake at 350 degrees for about 20-25 minutes (check after 15 mins) The quiche will be slightly wobbly in just the center.(this allows for carry over cooking and will set up within a few minutes of exiting the oven)
7. Allow to cool for about 20 minutes to room temperature. Quiche can be served warm, cold, or room temperature.

2. Mandoline Shallots into thin rings - Approx. 2mm.

ALLERGENS: N/A
Prep:
- Basically, this is a bound puree of Cilantro and Mint. All of the other ingredients in this recipe are more there for context.
- Place all ingredients (and, it's OK to use ground coriander in this recipe, even without toasting it)(don't worry, other flavours in this recipe will pick up where it otherwise would have done its thing) into a Vitamix. Keep Xanthan Gum aside.
- Start the Vitamix, and slowly raise the speed setting until you're working with a fine puree of all of the aforementioned ingredients. On "High" (the button to the left of the speed setting nob), remove the plunger from the pitcher base, and add the Xanthan Gum while the mixture is moving.
- Keeping in mind while you're doing this that the base of the Vitamix will heat up, causing your greens inside this puree to become bitter and discolour. Therefore, it's best if this it done quickly - but do not sacrifice quality for haste!
- You should know, with this recipe, and all recipes requiring a binder like Xanthan Gum, how a thickener is doing in its job. To test this mixture, turn the Vitamix off, and dip the plunger into the mixture, then raise it to see how slowly it falls off the plunger. It should fall slowly. If it doesn't, add more Xanthan Gum binder, and continue. The idea is that this will become a paste that will get things dipped into it.
- Don't worry - if you thicken it too much, you can always go backwards and let it out again, easily. This is not like over-cooking a steak. That said, know what you're looking for, and do it.

PREP RECIPE
Assemble all ingredients.
1. Char onions, ginger, leek whites, daikon and cabbage in that order.
2. While your veggies are charing, fill your kettle with 60L and pop in the Kombu and let it steep in warm water for 30 minutes. Take the Kombu out and save for Miso Soup.
3. Sautee your charred ginger and garlic. Add onions, leeks and celery.
4. Add sauteed veggies to the kettle and start filling with the rest of the water, leaving room for the Daikon and Cabbage. - Start heating up kettle to boil.
5. While the kettle is coming to temp, add Umami Dust - and any MUSHROOM ENDS that may be around. Some tomato ends are acceptable too.
6. Once the Daikon and Cabbage are done charring, cut into large chunks.
7. When Broth comes to a boil, turn it down to a very low simmer and add the daikon, cabbage and nori sheets. Season a bit at this stage too, as it helps draw out the flavour of the veggies.
8. If you are leaving the broth over night, you can add all the leek ends and any random cilantro/parsley/green onion ends to the broth while on low heat. If you are finishing it on the same day, then add the green ends at the end and let steep for 30 min before straining etc...
To finish.
1. Scoop all the veggies out. 2. Re-up with water and bring to a boil. 3. Turn down the kettle and add add 1 jug of soy sauce, taste and add more salt/pepper as needed. 4. Put through fine strainer and cool.
Label, date, refrigerate.

Prep:
- Take the Coriander Seeds, Cumin Seeds, Ajwain Seeds, Black Pepper and Garam Masala - and toast, then grind in the Vitamix into a fine powder. The toasting, as mentioned in other recipes, is key to developing flavour and aroma.
- Amchur Powder is not a spice, but a powder made of green mango. It should not be toasted. Opinions differ on this, but - for this recipe, do not toast this ingredient.
- Normally this recipe would be made into a paste with lemon juice and a small amount of water. We use this as a more dry rub, in combination with alread-wet ingredients like potatoes that have been boiled and chickpeas that sit in "aqua fava" (literally: bean water).
- If this spice mix is low, talk to a Chef about it. Some of these ingredients come from a specialty provider with an indented delivery schedule - and will need to be ordered several days in advance in order to allow for proper prep time.
Any questions - Ask Chef!

Prep:
- Basically, this is a bound gel of sweetened Tamarind Paste. 1 Jar is 300g, so the recipe is built around that.
- Fresh Tamarind, which isn't very widely available here in North America, is not very tart at all like Tamarind Paste. Citric Acid, other additives, and industrial processes force it to be this way - so it needs to be let out and sweetened. Allspice in this recipe is used to mask some of the bendinf that this ingredient must go through.
- Place all ingredients into a Vitamix. Keep Xanthan Gum aside.

To test this mixture, turn the Vitamix off, and dip the plunger into the mixture, then raise it to see how slowly it falls off the plunger. It should fall slowly. If it doesn't, add more Xanthan Gum binder, and continue. The idea is that this will become like a paste that will get things dipped into it.
- Don't worry - if you thicken it too much, you can always go backwards and let it out again, easily. This is not like over-cooking a steak. That said, know what you're looking for, and do it.

NOTES: I would prefer that this recipe be done in a Rondeau, and not the Combi Oven. If it must be done in the Combi Oven, the spice mixture with the Onions and Garlic (method below) should be cooked out before being mixed with the Rice and Accompaniment - stirred at least twice during the cooking process.
Prep:
- Small Dice Yellow Onions.
- Fine Chop the Preserved Lemon rinds. Cut the pith (white part) out of each, down to the zest only. Any pith that makes it into this recipe will spoil the flavours. Please take extra special care during this part of the process.
- Use Puree'd Garlic. Rough Chop Cilantro bunches, but do not add until the very end. Assemble spices.
- Using the Canola Oil in this recipe, begin to sautee the onions - cook them out, and add spices when they are done.
- Add Rice to sautee-ing Onions, and Spices. Garlic can be added at this stage - seasoning as well.
- Toast off Rice slightly, and then add water. At this point, add Sultana Raisins, Preserved Lemon, and Bay Leaf. Slowly raise to a boil (or do by Combi oven after these steps), and then cover with a lid, lower temperature, and let cook patiently for 25-30 minutes (this will depend on how far you toast out the Rice).
- If you are doing this in the Combi Oven, please make sure to saute the Onions out, the Spices, Garlic, and then add the remaining ingredients into the water that you use when you go to cook the Rice out. Cooking out the Onions and Spices in this recipe are key - Raisins, Preserved Lemon and Cilantro can and should be added very last prior to service.
- THIS ITEM SHOULD BE MADE ONCE IN THE MORNING AND ONCE AT NIGHT. THIS IS NOT AN ITEM THAT CAN SIT IN THE WARMERS ALL DAY - A PRACTICE THAT MUST BE STOPPED. IT SHOULD NOT BE MADE TOO FAR IN ADVANCE, AS IT WILL BECOME WASTE AND CANNOT REALLY BE RECYCLED.
Any questions - Ask Chef...

Method:
1.Drain Cannelini Beans. The Yield on these beans has been calculated in this recipe - roughly the loss of over a Kilogram in "Aqua Fava". A quick rinse is valued, but not entirely necessary.
2. Half all Grape Tomatoes. You will notice in this recipe that 5 LBS is the measured amount require. This is because each box of Grape Tomatoes that comes in from Freshpoint is 10 LBS - meaning: use half of a box for this recipe. Easy enough?
3. Small Dice yellow Onions. Saute with Cumin and Cayenne, adding 1 Bag of Frozen Corn and Red Pepper to the mix along the way. Do not roast this Corn in the oven for any reason - its starches develop and it becomes tough texturally. Deglaze this mixture with Apple Cider Vinegar, and season.
- Pick Oregano. Don't bother picking the Cilantro, as some stem is fine in this recipe. Rough Chop both of these, and reserve to add into the rest of this recipe.

ALLERGENS: N/A
Prep:
- Cut Potatoes into EQUAL SIZED pieces. This is not as important as the sizing on the Harra Potatoes recipe, since we're going to cook these ones in the Combi Oven, and then finish them off in the Convection Oven. Most of the work will be done in the Combi Oven.
- Really, this is a simple one. Cook your Potatoes out on the Steam (212F) setting on the Combi Oven. Do this until they're done - 30+ minutes.
- Once the potatoes are done, take them out and put them into a large mixing bowl, wherein you will add your Salt, Garlic, Sumac, and Thyme. Yeah, don't worry about the Thyme going in there whole. Don't even de-sprig it - once it roasts, it will fall off its sprigs, and then you can pull them out easily (try not to serve them to students, but, if a student gets one - no big deal; tell them to talk to the Chef).
- Tray these potatoes up, and Roast them off at 400F in the Convection Oven until browning. Do not roast them to the point where the Garlic is burning, but just shy of that point.
- Rough Chop your Arugula. Toss in at the very end, when your Potatoes (which are now ROASTED, like, no one will know that they were in the Combi Oven first...) are cooling down but still have enough heat left in them to wilt the Arugula.
Any questions? - Ask Chef...

ALLERGENS: N/A
Prep:
- Taking a Peeler, gently remove the zest from the Lemon and the Orange in long strips. Take half the juice from each, and set aside for the next step.
- Mandoline Garlic cloves thinly, and set into the juice of the orange and lemon to acidify. These will be added like this directly to the mixture - so, the thinner: the better.
- Steep the Thyme on low heat in the Olive Oil for 5 minutes. Afterwards, set aside oil to cool.
- Combine all ingredients.
NOTE: When these Marinated Olives come out of the fridge, the oil herein will have congealed. This leads to very unattractive presentation issues. Please temper any mixture you bring out - and don't bring out too much at a time that might lead to unnecessary waste.
Any questions? - Ask Chef...

Combine everything and blend until (mostly) smooth.

NOTES: This is a recipe where tasting is very important, as well as an understanding of what a product is or how it's supposed to taste. Each Item in this recipe has a specific process associated with it - when combined, it can be delicious.
Also, RE: ALLERGENS: it's important to know that there is no bread in this recipe. Only one item contains Wheat Fiber as an additive that makes it easier to use in a culinary setting.
Order Method:
1. Potatoes (>1" Cubes / Steamed) 2. Chickpeas (Pre-Cooked / Drained, Rinsed) 3. Tomatoes (Small Dice) 4. Cucumbers (Small Dice) 5. Red Onions (Fine Dice) 6. Chaat Spice (TOSS ALL AFOREMENTIONED ITEMS) 7. Salt (INCORPORATE WHEN TOSSING OTHERS)
8. Tamarind Chutney, Mint / Cilantro Chutney & Yogurt 9. Mint (Picked) & Cilantro (Rough Chop w/ Mint) 10. "Sev" (Dried Chickpea Noodle Snack)
Prep:
- Process the Potatoes in the Combi Oven on its Steam setting. Take Chickpeas out of can(s) (in appropriate weights).
- Cut all Vegetable ingredients. This step, and the one before it with the Potatoes and Chickpeas can be done in advance. Both can be combined, but kept separate for service (Potatoes and Chickpeas, then Tomatos, Red Onions and Cucumbers). Mint and Cilantro should be processed separately, but can be combined for service.
- Chutneys and Yogurt will be processed in advance, and the bottled for service. Chat spice should be kept separate.
- Combine all, and TASTE!

Notes: This is not a super-traditional Raita, just in case you were curious to know whether or not it was. Raita can vary in many ways based on where it's from - some even contain fruit! In order to make this stand out, in comparison to our Tzatziki, we will be using Ginger as an accent, and Cilantro, as well as Sev.
Prep:
- Using the Mandoline with the Medium "teeth" attachment, process the Zucchini into fine threads. Salt, and let sit for 25 minutes. The Salt will "cook" it, and break it down so that it will melt into this mixture.
- Puree Ginger. This can most likely be taken from the Ginger and Garlic purees in the Prepped Items Cooler. Combine this with the Lemon Juice and Sugar. Let this sit for 10 minutes.
- In a blanket of Cheese Cloth, drain all of the liquid from the Zucchini - give it a good squeeze to try and get all of the excess liquid (and Salt) out. Toss it in the Cardamom and Cayenne.
- Rough Chop Cilantro.
- Combine all other ingredients, and TASTE. Adjust for Salinity and Acidity. Ask Chef to taste. Then, TASTE AGAIN.
Any questions? - Ask Chef...

Related Products this prep gets used in: Allergens: (to be filled out by nutrition) Method:
NOTES: This recipe should be as green as possible - meaning: stewing the green elements of this recipe too far will kill the flavour and visual appeal of the recipe. The idea of this recipe is to have a flavourful earthy base to balance out the fats present in the Paneer (which is to be added last).
Prep:
1. Cut the root ends off of the Green Onions, and then grill them until coloured. Cool, and then chop up in pieces that are no less than 3 inches long.
2. Rough Chop Onions, and begin cooking them out immediately. Throw in Spices(toast spices) Garlic, and Ginger. Deglaze with veg stock. Season and simmer for 5-10 minutes.
3. Cut Paneer into bite-sized cubes - nothing too big. It will cut like Tofu, but it will also flake off..
4. Add HALF of the Spinach in the recipe, and cover for 5 minutes. You want the Spinach to be cooked out, but not to the point of bitterness. At this point, the recipe is very close to being taken off heat.
5. Add the Cilantro. Then, using an Immersion Blender, puree the Spinach and its juices into a sauce. This does not have to be a uniform puree as it would come out of a Vitamix - a little bit of texture is OK. Taste & check for seasoning.
6. Add Chopped Green Onions (grilled), Paneer, the other half of the Spinach, and the Cilantro - season again to taste using the salt in this recipe. Turn off heat.
7. Add Yogurt before moving this recipe intoserving pans. Reserve for service.

PREP RECIPE

ALLERGENS: N/A (BUT THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL)
Notes:
The most important part of this recipe is how to treat the fat that comes off of the Ground Beef when it’s sautéed – it must be drained off, and reserved for a slurry of sorts that’s made with potato starch nearer to the end of the recipe. If the fat is left in this recipe, it becomes a sloppy mess once it interacts with the tart shell that it is to go into.
Prep:
- Rough Chop Celery, Carrot, and Leek – process them in the RoboCoupe until they are roughly the size of a brunoise (a Mirepoix, but with Leek). DO NOT PROCESS THESE ITEMS INTO A PUREE.
- With the Spices involved in this recipe, cook out the Ground Beef. Drain off fat – reserve.
- In a Rondeau, sweat out the Leek Mirepoix. At the same time, pick your herbs and give them a rough chop – remember, do not bruise them by chopping up and down, instead use the knife you have like a saw with long back and forth strokes. You want to cook this mirepoix out fast and not too far – it just needs to lose some moisture.
- In the same Rondeau, add your Ground Beef back in with the mirepoix. Then, add your Maple Syrup. Then – after checking the seasoning – add your herbs, and then take off heat.
- Take your reserved fat from before, and put it in a pan, and put that pan on heat. Slowly add your potato starch to it – not all of it may be necessary depending on how much fat you pulled from the Ground Beef. You want to make a glue with this mixture, and then add it back into the Tourtierre mixture. Throw in a little Black Pepper if you find that the Allspice doesn’t come through.
- Mix thoroughly. Fill into 4” Tart Shells. Thaw tops, and use a fork to tamp down the edges of the Tart Shells to seal it shut. Egg wash is not used in this recipe to avoid listing that as an allergen, and also to cut a step. That said – use a knife to mark an X into the centre of each one to allow air to escape.
Tourtierres can be frozen (immediately after making, preferably), but are best kept in the fridge.
Any Questions? – Ask Chef

PREP RECIPE
Chop root veg.
Pick and chop thyme.
***Roast beets separately so that they don't dye everything red
Toss the potatoes, carrots and parsnips in the garlic oil, salt and pepper and chopped thyme.
Toss the beets with the same garlic oil, salt and pepper and chopped thyme, but separately.
Roast veggies in the oven until they are softened and sweet and golden brown around the edges.

Notes:
This recipe involves essentially making a stock from the Pork Bones inside the Festive Hams, and then discarding them – but keeping the Pork. The rest of the recipe is pretty easy.
Prep:
- Cut all of the Pork off of the Festive Hams, and small dice it, then set it aside.
- Roast Pork Bones in the Convection Oven for 30 minutes at 425F of above.
- Rough Chop Mirepoix vegetables: Onion, Carrot Celery. Make a Sachet D’epices with the Bay Leaf and Thyme.
- With a separate pot of water, cook out your Yellow Split Peas until they are done – approximately half an hour. This can be done on low heat, with minimal supervision. Add more water than is necessary, and top it up as the Split Peas expand.
- While those cook out, start sauteeing your Mirepoix vegetables. When they are cooked out, add the water, your Sachet, and make a stock – tossing in the roasted Pork Bones from the Convection Oven. Raise to a boil and then simmer for an hour or so. Discard Pork Bones and Sachet at this point, and add half of your cooked out Split Peas.
- You can add all of the other ingredients in the recipe at this point. Then, using an Immersion Blender, puree this mixture into a soup. Then, add your small diced Festive Ham, the other half of your Split Peas, and then season to taste.
- Add a slight acidity to it with the Apple Cider Vinegar, and again season to taste.
- Cool rapidly when off heat – this is a high protein dish, and will spoil faster than others.

ALLERGENS: SOY, SESAME
Notes:
This is a Wok-style recipe of Singaporean heritage. It is a rare dry curry - combining the Indian influences and the Chinese influences specific to Singapore. In Singapore it would have Prawns, Chicken, and Egg in it - these are considered Allergens to us and have therefore been avoided. Also, it's important to note that the name of this dish is loosely just the name of the Noodle itself - Singapore Bihon is like "Hokkien Mee", or "Hokkien Noodle".
Prep:
- Soak Bihon Noodles. Prepare Curried Tofu and Curried Chicken - recipes included in this binder.
- Prep all Vegetables with a stir-fry cut that will allow for them to be easily incorporated into the rice noodle whose name is loosely "Bihon" (Bee-Hoon). This noodle cooks quickly once it is soaked, and can be challenging to NOT tear up into a million tiny pieces through carelessness. It is most important to have this Mise En Place avaialble.
- Aggressively Wok Fry all vegetables - not Ginger and Garlic - in Canola Oil. Do not be afraid of a little colour. NOTE: You will have to multiply these volumes in order to make enough for services. These volumes should be seen as what should go into each plate. Notice this recipe's unit of measurement is "PTN" (Portion). Set aside these vegetables when finished.
- Using a Large Rondeau, start sautee-ing Garlic and Ginger on high heat, and then add soaked Noodles and Curry Powder. Add a little bit of water to create steam to finish off the noodles. Add Vegetables - and a small amount of Cornstarch Slurry - then tray for service. This, combined with Tofu or Chicken, AND Lime and Sprouts - will make a plate of Bihon Noodle. DO NOT OVER-PREPARE THIS DISH, AS ITS QUALITY WILL DEGRADE THE HIGHER IT IS SCALED OUT.
Any questions? Ask Chef...

ALLERGENS: N/A
Notes:
This is a vegetable mix for the Singapore Style Bihon Noodle. It's a base mix that can be steamed off lightly before being fried in the wok on high heat - and then assembled in a Rondeau with the Noodles and "Sauce" component.
The "Sauce" for the Bihon is actually more of a dry rub. There is no rubbing in this recipe - maybe it's best described as a dry spice mix that all of the component ingredients are tossed with.
After this process, there is another component - the fresh component: Bean Sprouts, Chopped Chilis, Coriander, and Fresh Lime Juice. Prawns and eggs are traditionally added to this - because: Singapore.
Any questions? - Ask Chef...

ALLERGENS: SOY, SESAME
Notes:
This is a "Sauce", in how it's used in this recipe, but not in terms of what you might think of when you hear the word "Sauce".
This dish is a dry spiced quasi-curry, with history specific to Singapore. In Singapore, the dominant population is Chinese, second to Indian and Malay people. Malay people have a wonderful array of curry-based dishes, and a mostly Muslim population which has its own spice character that is distinct to it in relation to India and its spice profiles.
This sauce contains a small amount of Corn Starch, which is to be used in it as a slurry, in order to properly coat the contents of this dish. It is not authentic in that regard, but, in the batch sizes that we'll be making, it is a necessity.
As you might expect - all of the ingredients in this recipe are to be cooked out, and formed into a paste to be used to start off each batch of Bihon. Cooking instructions will be included in the Product Recipe associated with this dish.
Any questions? - Ask Chef...

Notes:
This mixture is meant to simulate the famous "Tajin" Spice Mix that exists in Mexico and other parts of Central and South America. The only thing this imposter spice is missing is lime-infused salt - Citric Acid has been employed to make sure that it isn't missed much.
Bonus Points: to create lime-infused salt, simply zest 6 limes (for this recipe), and dehydrate overnight on a bed of Kosher Salt, and blitz up the next day in the Vitamix. If anyone actually does this - Chef will be impressed.

Prep:
- Garlic and Ginger - use the Pre-Minced products that are available in the prepped items fridge.
- Cut 1/3rd of a packet of Red Thai Chilis. Each packet that we get from Freshpoint is 300g.
- Large Dice: Cabbage, Onions,
- Heat the Wok. This side can be done at the station for effect or in the back, in hiding.
Either way --> THIS IS AN ITEM THAT SHOULD NEVER SIT IN OUR WARMERS, AS IT WILL LOOK HORRIBLE (WORSE THAN THE FACE THAT CHEF WILL MAKE IF THEY FIND IT IN THE WARMERS AT ANY POINT, OR BEING DONE AN HOUR BEFORE SERVICE), AND THE FLAVOURS WILL DEGRADE IMMENSELY.
- Starting with the Onions - in the hot Wok - begin to fry these ingredients. Spoiler - this is going to happen fast, and you're really just going to want to put some colour on the onions, before throwing in the Cabbage and deglazing with 2 Cups of Water. When you do this, throw in your Ginger and Garlic
- Add remaining ingredients, and bring to a boil. Immediately turn off heat at this point, and while it's still at a boil, make a Corn Starch Slurry out of your remaining Cup of Water in this recipe - adding it slowly while stirring. At this point, you're pretty much done.
- It would be best to do this infront of the students, as it will draw attention to the amazing job you're doing and the flavours that you're representing.

1) Remove kale leaves from the tough woody stem by tearing or running a knife along the stem to remove leaves.

1) Put strainer in the kettle. If you don't know what it looks like, ask someone. If you can't find it, ask a dishwasher. You will regret life if you do not do this step. Trust me.
2) In large kettle, bring water to a boil.
3) Add egg noodles and turn heat down by half. Simmer egg noodles for 3-5 minutes or until al dente.
4) Drain water. When water is completely drained, add cold water back into pot along with 3 grey lugs of ice. Until pasta is completely covered. mix gently.
5) Drain water and repeat step 4. It's very important to stir the pasta gently to ensure that it is cooled throughout, especially when making large batches.
6) Strain water again and add cooked pasta to appropriate vesself for storage. Add a small amount of oil and stir into noodles to avoid having them stick.

Notes:
Sushi Rice is never made in a Combi Oven in Japan. That doesn't matter. It can be simulated well enough to a respectable standard. I would prefer to have this made in a Rondeau, with a higher water ratio than what's suggested in this recipe, however, when you use the steam function in the Combi Oven you have to use a 1:1 ratio because of the excess humidity in the oven's chamber. Timing on this will depend on how many times the oven is opened and closed during the cooking process relative to other items being prepped - a suggested number will be put forth below.
Prep:
- Rinse Rice 3 times, or until the water from it becomes clear. In many cases, this will take more than 3 passes through COLD water.
- Once the Rice is cleaned, it should be drained effectively, and combined with its 1:1 water ratio for cooking. The steam function on our Combi Ovens, in case it isn't already going: 100% humidity w/ 212F/100C. Break up Lemongrass, and Slice up Ginger into chunks that you'll be able to take out after this process is over. DO NOT USE A GINGER PUREE for this recipe. Place the Rice in to steam.
- Combine Mirin, Rice Wine Vinegar and other ingredients into a bowl over ice. Or, place the bowl in the Freezer while the Rice cooks. THIS IS IMPORTANT, as it must help the rice cool down as much as possible, so as not to over-cook.
- Once Rice is cooked - 35+ minutes - take it out, and place in a large mixing bowl. Add the chilled liquid mixture, and mix around until evenly seasoned. BE CAREFUL NOT THE MASH IT UP. THIS IS EASY TO DO, AND WILL LEAD TO A STRANGE PRODUCT.
- Lay down on sheet trays if need be, and place in the fridge to cool down as soon as possible - stopping the cooking process.

***Portions for this recipe are 4 (fluid) oz - approximately 160g

Note:
This is a very simple recipe - combining one with the other. This will be a short write-up.
Prep:
- Using the Wok, on high heat with the small amount of oil, mark the Beef enough to get a little taste of burning. Again, the colour here will be balanced out by the Bulgogi Sauce - go ahead and burn it a little bit.
- When you're content that you've succeeded in giving the Beef a little burnt flavour, and that's it's cooked out, turn off the heat. As the wok is still hot though, add your Bulgogi Sauce, and let the temperature reduce until it's all ready to come out of the Wok as a mix.
- This is one of those things that you can get BONUS POINTS FROM CHEF for doing ON THE STATION during service or right at the beginning of service. It should NEVER BE DONE IN LARGE BATCHES PRIOR TO SERVICE IN A LARGE BATCH AND HELD HOT DURING SERVICE IN WASTEFUL BATCHES.

ALLERGENS: N/A
Notes:
This is a simple roast for the Burrito Bar, Bueno - all you need to know is that the Butternut Squash is to be peeled, seeded, and chopped up before roasting. A processed product will not be used in this recipe. Whenever possible, use as much UBC Squash as possible, as there will be an excess of it during the Fall/Winter season to use. UBC Squash cost in the system has been actualized to equal Freshpoint's cost.
Prep:
- Pre-heat Convection Oven to 375F/190C.
- Peel, Seed, and Chop Squash into 1" Cubes.
- Toss in Canola Oil, Salt, and Spices.
- Roast for 25 minutes, and then check! Alternatively, these Squash cubes can be steamed for 25-30 minutes, and then tossed in everything - Spices, Oil, Salt, AND Garlic - AND THEN finished in the Convection Oven.
- If you do not choose to steam the Squash beforehand, then only add the Garlic at the end of the roasting process - so as not to burn the Garlic.
- Roast until tender and cooked through - this will depend on the size of the cut / type of Squash - cool, and ready in the Bueno line in a hot-hold insert.
- Steam 2 Bags of the "7 Bean Medley" (Carb Freezer), and fold into the Roasted Squash as it cools.
- Label / Date / Store Appropriately...

Notes:
Like a baking recipe, this is the combination of 2 recipes - folded together once they're both complete. Sesame and Tree Nuts have been taken out of this recipe to navigate dietary restrictions and priority allergens. This mixture can be made in advance and bagged/frozen.
Prep:
- Put a Rondeau on heat, and let it go until it gets red-hot. Toss in corn, and deglaze 2 minutes later with water - allowing a small amount of the corn to get some colour. Stir and Salt. Cook corn out until soft, and then take off heat to cool.
- Using Lime Juice and Water, as well as Xanthan Gum to bind, blitz this mixture in a Vitamix with the Silken Tofu until smooth.
- Fold Mole 2.0 into Corn and Silken tofu puree, and check seasoning.

1) Make vegetable stock as per recipe.
2) Cook lentils by covering in water and bringing up to a simmer for about 10 minutes until al dente. Check for doneness, and make sure to not over cook or split lentils.
3) Spread lentils out on a sheet pan and allow to cool.
4) In the mean time, make soup base.
5) Add oil to large rondeau over medium high heat. When oil is hot, add onions and allow to saute for 3-4 minutes. Add salt and pepper and curry powder and allow to cook out for about 5 minutes more. Add carrots and serrano peppers and saute for another 3-4 minutes.
5) Add Vegetable stock and bring to a simmer. Allow to simmer for about 10 minutes. Check carrots for doneness, they should be nice and tender. Once carrots are cooked, puree mixture with immersion blender.
6) Pass mixture through china cap, then add coconut milk. Mix well to incorporate. Add lentils and mix well, but try not to split the lentils.
7) Label, date, refrigerate.

Process the squash and veggies.

PREP RECIPE
1) Split pork loin in to quarters lengthwise. Should have 4 tube like pieces. In shallow pan or bag marinate pork for 24 hours making sure it's fully covered by the marinade.
2) Remove from marinade and roast at 425F on wire racks on sheet pans until an internal temp of 165F is achieved. Reserve any pan drippings.
3) Allow the meat to rest. keep warm for service. Do not let rest for too long before service, try and have it ready about 30 mintues before service and make in batchs so you have fresh ones as much as possible to stop it from drying out.
4) Carve at station under hot lamp per order to 115g. Garnish with chopped green onions, pour any pan drippings back over the top for flavour and moisture.

1) Toast peppercorn in a DRY pan over medium low heat until fragrent. Then put cardamom and peppercorn into cheeesecloth (sachet). Toast rest of the spices DRY in the same pan over medium low heat, until fragrant; set aside.
2) In the roasting pans oil and season lamb with salt and pepper then put on roasting pans (1 box per pan) roast at 500 in combi oven, until fully browned but not cooked through about 10 minutes.
3) While lamb is roasting in the oven, In tilt skillet at 325, add oil and when the oil is hot add, 1/4inch dice onion. Cook until dark brown then add chop garlic saute until browned and soft. Add tomatoes, chili flakes and toasted spices including sachet cooking and stirring 2-3 minutes.
4) Add seared lamb and chopped mint and cilantro. Cover, reduce heat to a simmer; cook until lamb is tender, about 1hour. Add water if curry gets too dry.
5) Adjust seasoning w/ salt/ pepper.
6) Transfer, cool, label/date and store.

Method:
1) Set milk out to warm up while doing other steps.
2) In pot melt the butter over medium heat
3) Add the flour through fine mesh chinois while whisking melted butter to insure that no lumps are formed.
4) Stir until the mixture is smooth and with out lumps, this is the time to be more careful. Cook for 1 minute so the flour becomes tastier and absorbs the fats. The roux should be a nice golden colour.
5) Add warm milk to roux in a steady stream, whisking continuously. Simmer on low heat until it starts to thicken, but insure it does not come to a boil. Whisk in the salt and pepper mix, and nutmeg, taste for seasoning and adjust if needed. Set aside for recipe.

1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
2. Dock the bottom of the pastry (to allow air to escape so it doesn't bubble) Bake the crust for about 5-10 minutes.
3. Remove from the oven and allow to cool. The crust will be golden. but not not too dark. (as it will bake again with custard/filling
4. Prepare the egg custard mixture by adding the eggs to a large measuring cup. Add the heavy cream, then add the milk, salt and pepper.
5. Blend with a hand mixer to ensure the egg and cream mixture is completely homogenous (mixed thouroughly)
6. Spread the desired fillings on the bottom of the pie crust. Pour the egg mixture on top (leave a 1/2 cm of head space at the top of the quiche as the eggs will souffle and expand) Bake at 350 degrees for about 20-25 minutes (check after 15 mins) The quiche will be slightly wobbly in just the center.(this allows for carry over cooking and will set up within a few minutes of exiting the oven)
7. Allow to cool for about 20 minutes to room temperature. Quiche can be served warm, cold, or room temperature.

Allergens: (to be filled out by nutrition) Method:
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
2. Dock the bottom of the pastry (to allow air to escape so it doesn't bubble) Bake the crust for about 5-10 minutes.
3. Remove from the oven and allow to cool. The crust will be golden. but not not too dark. (as it will bake again with custard/filling
4. Prepare the egg custard mixture by adding the eggs to a large measuring cup. Add the heavy cream, then add the milk, salt and pepper.
5. Blend with a hand mixer to ensure the egg and cream mixture is completely homogenous (mixed thouroughly)
6. Spread the desired fillings on the bottom of the pie crust. Pour the egg mixture on top (leave a half CM of head space at the top of the quiche as the eggs will souffle and expand) Bake at 350 degrees for about 20-25 minutes (check after 15 mins) The quiche will be slightly wobbly in just the center.(this allows for carry over cooking and will set up within a few minutes of exiting the oven)
7. Allow to cool for about 20 minutes to room temperature. Quiche can be served warm, cold, or room temperature.

Preps used in this Product recipe:
Allergens: (To be filled out by nutrition) Method:
1.Place all your rice noodles in a deep mixing bowl, (trying to snap as few of them as possible as you remove them from the package). Bring a good amount of water to boil. Pour the boiling water over the rice noodles until they are completely submerged.
2. Stir constantly to prevent clumping/sticking. When they are completely limp, give them a taste to see if they’re cooked through. The thread-like vermicelli noodles will cook through in just a few minutes. The flat rice noodles might take upwards of ten minutes depending on thickness. Pay attention and test the noodles frequently because they’ll become mushy if they overcook.
3. Once the noodles are tender, drain them and run them under cool water to stop the cooking. Toss them with a small bit of sesame oil to keep the noodles from sticking to each other if you’re not going to use them right away.
4. The noodles will be used in a stir-fry dish like pad thai, you definitely want to under-cook them a little bit. They will absorb more moisture and cook the rest of the way through once in the stir fry. If your noodles are perfectly cooked to start, they will turn to mush in the stir fry.
NOTE: Even with a bit of sesame oil, the noodles still tend to clump up after you drain them. They will loosen again once you mix the noodles into your dish

Method - peel pumpkin, remove seeds, cut into even sized chunks - roast in 350f oven for 10 - 15 min or until tender and slightly dry looking - remove from heat, keeping warm - peel and boil the potato until fork tender. - remove from heat, allow to vent off steam for a few minutes then hold warm for preparation. - place flour on a work surface, make a well, pass the pumpkin through a ricer directly onto the flour, add salt, pepper, nutmeg - work the warm ingredients together using a fork until combined ( mix as little as possible ). - wisk the egg in a separate bowl, make a well in the pumpkin mixture, incorporate the egg with as little mixing as possible - once combined, form the dough into a large ball. - cut off a piece of dough and roll out on a floured surface into a 1" diameter "snake" - cut the dough into 1" pieces. - once all of the dough has been cut, place on a sheet pan with parchment ( keeping pieces separated so they dont stick together ) - place in freezer - for service, blanch in salted boiling water until they float. - remove from boiling water - place in non stick pan with sage butter, sear, - remove from pan, toss with roasted apples - top with toasted hazelnuts, crisp sage leaves - finish dish with shaved parmesan

PREP RECIPE
Make veg stock by combining water and vegetable base. heat in a pot and reserve and set aside.
Melt butter in a separate pot and saute onions until transluscent and then add garlic, stir garlic in and continue to cook for another minute or two.
Add arborio rice to pot and stir it through the onion and garlic and butter and toast the grains of rice in the butter for a minute or two.
Before the rice begins to catch and stick, deglaze with white wine and stir the wine through the rice, cooking the wine away to nearly dry before adding stock.
Now add stock, incrementally stirring frequently and thoroughly between additions.
Add stock until the rice is very tender, in arancini, the risotto should be well past al dente.
At the end of the cooking, mix through the parmesan and fresh chopped thyme.
Taste and adjust seasoning.
Lay out on a parchment lined sheet pan to cook thoroughly before balling

PREP RECIPE
Chop all veggies and gather mise en place
Dilute the vegetable stock concentrate in the water
Make the cornstarch slurry
To Cook- add oil to a hot wok and add garlic and ginger.
Strifry the garlic and ginger to toast and and develop flavour.
Add the vegetables to the wok and stirfry in oil, deglazing with the vegetable stock and soya sauce to both prevent burning and sticking and to provide steam to cook out the vegetables.
A moment before the veggies are cooked to their sufficient doneness, add the cornstarch slurry and stirfry it through to give the broth/sauce some body, so that it will cling to the veggies.
Hold or serve.

4.To Cook; Add oil to a hot wok and add 1/2 of the garlic and ginger.

6. Add the beef to the wok to the wok and stirfry in oil, browning the exterior- remove from the wok and set aside.
7. Stirfry the other half of the garlic and ginger until softened, then add the onion and cook out to soften, add the broccoli deglazing with the vegetable stock and soy sauce to both prevent burning and sticking and to provide steam to cook out the vegetables.
8. Add the brown sugar and mix.
9. Add the beef back in and combine and toss.

Portioning:
Utensils needed:

1. Assemble all ingredients.

3. Label, date, refrigerate.

This recipe also requires 12 cans of guniness beer.
Please ensure you add this before simmering.
Notes:
Prep:
Saute each of the vegetables (Mushroom, Onion/garlic, leek, parsnip, turnip, potato ) separately with oil, salt & pepper.
Deglaze the pan with guiness in between each vegetable, reserving the liquid
Once all vegetables are cooked to 70%, start a roux with butter & flour. Toast until golden - incorporate the deglazing liquid and stock into the roux using a wand mixer to remove any lumps - add the vegetables and herbs - cook over medium heat and simmer until it thickens - simmer until the flour has "cooked out" - finish the stew with the peas and parsley - adjust seasoning and hold for service
- The Sauce will start simply, as most sauces do. Get your Onions, Celery (3Kg for Sauce: 3Kg for Vegetables), Garlic, and Leek – rough chop them, and begin sautéing – Onions and Garlic first. Once the Garlic and Onions are cooked out – add the reserved Lamb liquid to the mixture, and let simmer.
- You may need to add a little more water to this. Don’t worry – it will have enough flavour. You want to make as much of this Sauce as you can, since this is a big batch size.
- Once this Sauce is boiling, use the Roux that you made out of the Lamb fat, and the Immersion Blender, to blend the Roux into the sauce to thicken it. You will want to turn the heat down on this pot, as the Roux will be tempted to burn if you do this on high heat. Within a few minutes, the gluten will cook out, and you’ll know the thickness of your sauce shortly after that. Season then, to taste.
- Meanwhile, begin processing the Vegetables and Herbs for this recipe in the background. Have the Herbs picked. The Vegetables can be cut in advance, and even cooked off in advance.
- All of the Vegetables – Parsnips, Rutabaga (Turnip), and Celery – would be best steamed until cooked, and then roasted at 350F in the Convection ovens for 15-20 minutes.
- When these are done, they can be set aside to be combined with everything else in this next step.
- When combining everything – Dumplings, braised Lamb, Vegetables, Sauce – the last things to add will be the herbs, and the peas. The peas will add a small amount of moisture and flavour to the batch, and the Herbs will finish it off. Go overboard on the herbs, making sure that everything that is ordered is in this recipe, and not waiting to die in our Produce Fridge’s shelves. The more herbs – the better!

Method:
1.Cut the sausage into 1/4 inch rounds. In a large rondeau sear the chicken and sausage. Cook until the chicken is cooked through and the sausage is lightly browned. remove chicken and sausage reserve.
2. In the same rondeau (leaving the good bits of chicken and sausage on the bottom of the pan to add flavour) Sauté the onion, bell pepper, celery, jalapeño and garlic until soft and translucent.
3. Add rice, liquids and seasonings. Add in the uncooked rice, chicken stock, crushed tomatoes, old bay seasoning, oregano, cayenne and bay leaf. Give everything a good stir. reduce to low flame.
4. Cover and cook 25-30 minutes, being sure to stir the mixture every 5 minutes or so (to prevent burning) until the rice is nearly tender.
5. Add the shrimp (cut the shripm in half). And cook for a final 5 minutes or so, until the shrimp is pink and opaque.
6. Add the chicken and sausage back in.
7. Taste and adjust seasoning as needed.

Method:
1. Combine the orange juice, olive oil, cilantro, lime juice, lemon juice, white wine vinegar, cumin, salt, black pepper, jalapeno, and garlic in a large mixing bowl and whisk together until it is well blended. Save 250ml of the marinade in a covered container in the refrigerator.
2. Combine the remaining marinade and steak in a large covered insert. Refrigerate the steak in the marinade for at least 2 hours, or overnight.
3. Preheat your grill to high heat, Make sure the grill is hot before you start to cook the meat.
4. Remove the steak from the marinade and pat dry. Discard any leftover marinade.
5. Add the steak to the preheated grill and cook for 6 to 8 minutes per side, or until you’ve reached your desired doneness. Note that flank steak tastes best when it is cooked to medium-rare because it’s a lean cut of steak. Use an instant read meat thermometer to check the temperature for accuracy.
6. Remove the steak from the heat and let it rest for 10 minutes. Giving the steak time to rest is very important!
7. Once the steak has had time to rest for 10 minutes, thinly slice the steak against the grain and serve it with the 250ml of reserved merinade.
**Please note – the cooking time is estimated! This will depend on how thick the steak is. To check the temperature of your meat, Use an instant read thermometer for accuracy. The health board recommends that steak be cooked to an internal temperature of 145F

Allergens: (to be filled out by nutrition) Method:
1. Heat oven to 425F
2. In a large rondeau, heat half of oil over medium-high heat. Working in batches so the mushrooms brown evenly, add half the mushrooms, season with salt and pepper and cook, undisturbed, until browned underneath, about 3 minutes. Stir the mushrooms, then continue to cook until browned all over, about 3 minutes.
3. Transfer to a bowl. Repeat with remaining oil and the remaining mushrooms; transfer them to the medium bowl. Season with salt and pepper and cook, stirring occasionally, until browned and tender, 6 to 8 minutes, lowering the heat as needed to avoid burning. Transfer to the bowl.
4. Reduce the heat to medium and add the butter to the skillet. Once the butter is melted, add the onion, cook until starting to soften, about 5 minutes.
5. Add the kale, garlic, thyme and rosemary, season with salt and pepper and cook out, stirring occasionally, until softened, approx 3 minutes, adding 1 to 2 tablespoons oil if the pan seems dry. Sprinkle with the flour and cook, stirring, until flour is dispersed and lightly toasted, 2 minutes.
6. Stirring constantly, gradually add the stock and cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until thickened, about 5 minutes.
7. Mix in the parsnips, celery, potatoes, and the sautéed mushrooms and any accumulated juices. Cook untill potatoes and carrots are fork tender. finish with cream and reduce slightly.
8. Taste for seasoning and adjust as needed.

***COOKS AND CHEFS, PLEASE READ THE ENTIRE RECIPE BEFORE BEGINNING- THIS IS A RECOMMENDED STEP WITH EVERY PRODUCT WE EVER PRODUCE- THANK YOU*** Amanda
Related Products this prep gets used in:
Allergens: (to be filled out by nutrition) Method:
1.Dry the beef with a few paper towels for better browning. Sear the beef on all sides in a rondeau. Set aside.
2. In the Rondeau once the beef is removed, add the diced carrots and onions; sautée in fat until browned, about 3 minutes.
3. Add the beef back to the pot. Season with coarse salt and pepper. stir. Sprinkle the flour over everything and stir to coat everything evenly. Place in the center of the oven for 5 minutes @ 400F
4. Remove pot from oven; Stir beef and place back in the oven for 4 more minutes. Remove the rondeau from the oven and reduce the heat to 325°F.
5. To the rondeau, add the wine and stock. The liquid should barely cover the meat and vegetables. Add the tomato paste, garlic and thyme. Bring to a light simmer on the stove top, then cover and simmer in the oven for 3 to 4 hours, or until the meat fork tender and is easily pierced.
6. In the last hour of cooking, bring 1 1/2 tablespoons butter and 2 teaspoons oil to a medium heat in a sauté pan. Add the pearl onions and toss around in the fat until they've browned, 8-10 minutes. Then stir in 250ml of beef stock, a small pinch of salt and pepper and the herbs bundle. Reduce the heat to low and simmer the onions for about 20 minutes, until the liquid has evaporated, and the onions are tender.
7. Remove the onions and set aside. Discard the herb bundle and wipe out the skillet. Add the remaining butter and oil and bring to a medium heat.
8. Add the mushrooms and cook for about 5 minutes, shaking the pan to coat with the butter.
9.Place a colander over a large pot. Drain the beef stew through the colander and into the pot. Place the pot with the sauce over a medium heat and simmer for about 5 minutes, skimming any fat on top. Pour the beef and vegetables back into therondeau. Add the pearl onions and mushrooms to the pot. Pour the sauce over the beef mix and simmer an additional 3 to 5 minutes.
*Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently

1. Heat a large pot over medium heat. Once hot, add oil, onion, cumin, and one-third of the salt.(Adjust if altering batch size).
2. Add garlic, ginger, cilantro, and green chilies to Robot coupe to pulse into a paste. Then, add to the pan with the onions.
3. Next add ground coriander, chili powder, and turmeric and stir to coat. Add a little more oil at this point if the pan is looking dry.
4. Next add pureed tomatoes and chickpeas and remaining salt. If the mixture looks a little too thick, add up to 1 cup (250 ml) water. You’re looking for a semi-thick soup consistency at this point, as it will cook down into more of a stew.
5. Increase heat to medium high until it reaches a rolling simmer, then reduce heat to low or medium-low and maintain a simmer (uncovered) for 15-20 minutes, or until thick and stew-like. Stir occasionally.
6. When the chana masala is thickened and bubbly, taste and adjust seasonings as needed, add more salt if needed.
7. Remove from heat and add lemon juice and garam masala. Stir to mix.
Hot hold/serve immediately

Related Products this prep gets used in:
Allergens: (to be filled out by nutrition) Method:
1. Gather all ingredents. Using a larger pot than you think you will need (caramel expands and foams up once you add the cream to the hot sugar mixture) Caramel is a fast process and you cannot walk away from it. if you don't work fast once the sugar is ready, it will burn.Scale out all ingredents make sure the butter is cubed and cold.
2. Add Water and sugar to a heavy bottom sauce pan. turn on medium high heat DO NOT WALK AWAY. This recipe needs undevided attention.
3. Allow sugar to fully disolve. As the sugar melts, stir vigerously with a whisk or wooden spoon (nothing plastic or it will melt!) reduce heat once the sugar has fully melted.
3. once the sugar has melted stop stiring (you can swirl the pan but do not stir with a utensil)
4. As soon as the sugar turns to a dark amber colour, remove from heat and ad the cold butter, whisk until the butter is melted. Once butter is fully melted, add the heavy cream (using caution as hot steam will happen and the cream will foam up considerably) Whisk until smooth and homogenous(well blended) Let Cool! once cool enough to pour into a cambro do so, but let sit out without a lid until reaches room tempature.
*Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently
